entities.description: "CONCEPTNET is a graph knowledge base used for extracting subgraphs and triplets for crowdsourcing to generate questions."
"Amazon Mechanical Turk is used for crowdsourcing workers to generate and validate commonsense questions."
"Google is used for issuing web queries to add textual context to each question in the data generation process."
"COMMONSENSEQA is the event of generating questions that require commonsense knowledge and can be easily answered by humans without context."
"Figure 2 is a visual representation of the COMMONSENSEQA generation process, showing the input and output of the process."
"Figure 1 illustrates the process of creating question sets from triplets in CONCEPTNET for crowdsourcing."
"Crowdsourcing workers are individuals who contribute to the generation and validation of commonsense questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"The question concept is the starting point for generating multiple-choice questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"The answer concept is the target that crowdsourcing workers aim to correctly answer in the multiple-choice questions generated for COMMONSENSEQA."
"Distractors are additional incorrect answers added to questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process to make them more challenging."
"Web snippets are textual contexts retrieved from search engines to provide relevant context to each question in the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."
"Verifiers are a group of workers responsible for the quality check of the generated questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"NLP likely refers to the field of Natural Language Processing, which is relevant to the context of generating and understanding commonsense questions."
"Edit distance is a measure used to filter triplets in the CONCEPTNET knowledge base, ensuring diversity in the questions generated for COMMONSENSEQA."
"Commonsense relations are the types of connections between concepts in CONCEPTNET that carry commonsense knowledge used in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"Natural language concepts are the nodes in CONCEPTNET that represent ideas used to generate questions for the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."

relationships.description: "CONCEPTNET provides the knowledge base for generating questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"Amazon Mechanical Turk workers are used to generate and validate questions for the COMMONSENSEQA event."
"Google is utilized to add textual context to questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process by issuing web queries."
"Figure 2 summarizes the COMMONSENSEQA generation process, visually depicting the steps involved."
"Figure 1 is part of the explanation of how question sets are created for the COMMONSENSEQA event."
"Crowdsourcing workers use CONCEPTNET to generate and validate questions based on the triplets extracted from the knowledge base."
"The question concept and answer concept are the two main components used to create multiple-choice questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"Distractors are incorrect answers added to multiple-choice questions to increase difficulty, in relation to the question concept."
"Web snippets provide contextual information to enhance the COMMONSENSEQA questions, aiding in their comprehension."
"Verifiers ensure the quality of the questions generated for the COMMONSENSEQA event by annotating and validating them."
"NLP is related to the use and exploration of commonsense relations within CONCEPTNET for generating questions."
"Edit distance is a criterion used within CONCEPTNET to filter triplets for the COMMONSENSEQA question generation process."
"Commonsense relations are the types of edges in CONCEPTNET that represent the connections between natural language concepts."
"Natural language concepts are the nodes in CONCEPTNET that are connected by commonsense relations to form triplets."

"CONCEPTNET is used for generating difficult questions at scale for the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."

entities.description: "Alon Talmor is one of the authors of the COMMONSENSEQA challenge paper, affiliated with the School of Computer Science, Tel-Aviv University and the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence."

"COMMONSENSEQA is a challenging new dataset for commonsense question answering presented in the paper, aiming to investigate question answering with prior knowledge."
"CONCEPTNET is a knowledge base from which the COMMONSENSEQA dataset extracts multiple target concepts that have the same semantic relation to a single source concept."
"BERT-large is a model used as a baseline in the COMMONSENSEQA challenge, achieving 56% accuracy, well below human performance."
"Simon is mentioned in an example question about spatial relations and common sense understanding."
"Lawn Mower is used in an example question to illustrate common sense knowledge about spatial relations."
"River is a source concept in the COMMONSENSEQA dataset, used to generate questions about related target concepts."
"Waterfall is a target concept related to the source concept 'River' in the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."
"Bridge is a target concept related to the source concept 'River' in the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."
"Valley is a target concept related to the source concept 'River' in the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."

"Island is mentioned as a distractor in a question about the location on a river to see water falling without getting wet."
"Bank is mentioned as a distractor in a question about crossing the river with feet wet but body dry."

entities.description: "COMMONSENSEQA is an event or process where commonsense questions are generated and evaluated, aiming to test models' understanding of commonsense knowledge."
"CONCEPTNET is a knowledge base used as the input for generating commonsense questions in the COMMONSENSEQA process."
"BERT-LARGE is a pre-trained model developed by Devlin et al. (2018), which when fine-tuned on COMMONSENSEQA, achieves the best performance among evaluated models."
"Devlin et al. are the creators of BERT-LARGE, a model that has been fine-tuned and evaluated on the COMMONSENSEQA dataset."
"Gordon and Van Durme are researchers cited in the text, contributing to the understanding of reporting bias on the web."
"McCarthy is a researcher mentioned in the text, associated with early work on reasoning about an environment in natural language."
"Winograd is a researcher mentioned in the text, known for the Winograd Schema Challenge, a benchmark for machine common sense."
"Levesque is a researcher who created the Winograd Schema Challenge, a dataset for evaluating machine common sense."
"Roemmele et al. are researchers responsible for the Choice of Plausible Alternatives (COPA) dataset, which is used for evaluating cause or effect relations."
"Zhang et al. are researchers behind the JHU Ordinal Commonsense Inference dataset, which focuses on predicting relations between situations."
"Mostafazadeh et al. are the creators of the Story Cloze Test (ROC Stories), a dataset that evaluates the ability to choose plausible story endings."
"Zellers et al. are researchers behind the Situations with Adversarial Generations (SWAG) dataset, which asks models to predict what happens next in a scenario."
"Radford et al. are researchers who have worked on LM-based techniques for fine-tuning pre-trained language models on target tasks."
"Gururangan et al. are researchers who have investigated the difficulty of creating benchmarks that measure program understanding rather than distributional biases."
"Poliak et al. are researchers who have also investigated the challenges in creating benchmarks for common sense in natural language datasets."
"Davis is a researcher who created SQUABU, a small hand-curated test of common sense and science questions."
"Ostermann et al. are researchers who have focused on science questions that often require common sense, in addition to specialized scientific knowledge."
"Winograd's work in 1972 is an event in AI history, where leveraging a world-model for deeper language understanding is explored."
"McCarthy and Hayes' work in 1969 is an event in AI, where commonsense representations and inference procedures are explored."
"Kowalski and Sergot's work in 1986 is an event in AI, where commonsense representations and inference procedures are further explored."
"Lenat's work in 1995 is an event in AI, where large-scale commonsense knowledge-bases are developed."
"Speer et al.'s work in 2017 is an event in AI, contributing to the development of large-scale commonsense knowledge-bases."
"Zellers et al.'s work in 2018 is an event in AI, where the Situations with Adversarial Generations (SWAG) dataset is introduced."

"Schwartz et al.'s work in 2017 is an event in AI, where annotation artifacts in the Story Cloze Test are investigated."
"Cai et al.'s work in 2017 is an event in AI, where annotation artifacts in the Story Cloze Test are further investigated."
"Clark et al.'s work in 2018 is an event in AI, where question answering that utilizes common sense, particularly in science questions, is studied."
"Mihaylov et al.'s work in 2018 is an event in AI, focusing on question answering that requires common sense in the context of science questions."
"Machine common sense refers to the knowledge of and ability to reason about an open-ended world, which is critical for natural language understanding."
"Natural language understanding is the ability of a system to comprehend and process human language in a manner similar to human understanding."
"Reporting bias refers to the倾向 of not reporting certain types of information due to its being considered trivial or obvious, which affects the availability of background knowledge on the web."
"Fine-tuning is the process of further training a pre-trained model on a specific task, with the aim of adapting it to that task."

entities.description: "LM1B-REP is a model that clusters questions based on their first two words and rephrases them to contain the answer, covering 35% of the development set."
"QABILINEAR is a model proposed by Yu et al. (2014) for QA, which scores answers using a bilinear model and trains with cross-entropy loss."
"QACOMPARE is a model similar to an NLI model from Liu et al. (2016), representing the interaction between the question and candidate answer, and predicting an answer score."
"ESIM is a strong NLI model used by Chen et al. (2016), with modifications to the output layer size for candidate answers and trained with cross-entropy loss."
"BIDAF++ is a state-of-the-art RC model that uses Google web snippets as context, augmented with a self-attention layer and ELMo representations, adapted for multiple-choice settings."
"GPT is a method proposed by Radford et al. (2018) for adapting pre-trained LMs to perform a wide range of tasks, applied to COMMONSENSEQA by encoding questions and candidate answers as sequences."

"BERT is a model that fine-tunes a language model and holds state-of-the-art across a broad range of tasks, using a masked language modeling objective and fine-tuning pre-trained weights for COMMONSENSEQA."
"COMMONSENSEQA is the task used to evaluate and fine-tune models like BERT and GPT, with a focus on accuracy and understanding of commonsense knowledge."
"SWAG is an event or task for which BERT's hyper-parameters were set, as mentioned in the context of fine-tuning BERT."
"ROC Stories is an event or task for which the GPT model's pre-trained LM and hyper-parameters were used, as referenced in the GPT model's application to COMMONSENSEQA."
"Liu et al. (2016) are the authors associated with the NLI model that QACOMPARE is similar to, representing the interaction between the question and candidate answer."
"Chen et al. (2016) are the authors of the ESIM model, a strong NLI model used with modifications for candidate answers."
"Seo et al. (2016) are the authors who originally developed BIDAF, which was later augmented to form BIDAF++."
"Peters et al. (2018) are associated with the development of ELMo representations, which are used in the BIDAF++ model."
"Huang et al. (2018) are associated with the development of ELMo representations, which are used in the BIDAF++ model."
"Radford et al. (2018) proposed the GPT model for adapting pre-trained LMs to perform a wide range of tasks, including COMMONSENSEQA."
"Devlin et al. (2018) are associated with the development of BERT, which uses a masked language modeling objective for various tasks."
"Pennington et al. (2014) are the authors behind the development of 300d GloVe embeddings, used in pre-trained word embeddings."
"Speer et al. (2017) are the authors behind the development of 300d Numberbatch CONCEPTNET node embeddings, used in pre-trained word embeddings."
"Zellers et al. (2018b) are associated with modifications made to the ESIM model, changing the output layer size to the number of candidate answers."
"Numberbatch is the source of the 300d CONCEPTNET node embeddings used in pre-trained word embeddings."
"CONCEPTNET is related to the node embeddings used in pre-trained word embeddings, developed by Speer et al. (2017)."
"ELMo representations are used in the BIDAF++ model, contributing to its ability to adapt to multiple-choice settings."

relationships.description: "QABILINEAR is a model used in the COMMONSENSEQA task for scoring answers with a bilinear model."
"QACOMPARE is a model used in the COMMONSENSEQA task, representing the interaction between questions and candidate answers."

"GPT is a model applied to the COMMONSENSEQA task by encoding questions and candidate answers as sequences."
"BERT is a model fine-tuned for the COMMONSENSEQA task, using a masked language modeling objective."
"QACOMPARE is similar to the NLI model from Liu et al. (2016), representing the interaction between questions and candidate answers."

"COMMONSENSEQA is a dataset that focuses on commonsense questions, building on CONCEPTNET and aiming to challenge current NLU models."
"CONCEPTNET is a knowledge base containing concepts and relations, which COMMONSENSEQA is built upon."
"Person is a question concept in COMMONSENSEQA, representing a category of questions."
"Human is a question concept in COMMONSENSEQA, related to questions about human behavior or characteristics."
"Water is a question concept in COMMONSENSEQA, likely related to geographical or natural phenomena."
"Cat is a question concept in COMMONSENSEQA, possibly related to geographical分布 or as a concept in questions."
"Question formulators are individuals who contributed to the creation of questions for COMMONSENSEQA, with a significant contribution from a smaller group of workers."
"LoBue and Yates are referenced in the analysis of commonsense skills needed to answer questions in COMMONSENSEQA."
"VECSIM is a model used as a baseline in the evaluation of COMMONSENSEQA, based on cosine similarity of pre-trained word embeddings."
"Trinh and Le are referenced in the context of the LM1B model used as a baseline in the evaluation of COMMONSENSEQA."
"Jozefowicz et al. are associated with the pre-trained large language model (LM) used in the LM1B variations for evaluating COMMONSENSEQA."
"Chelba et al. are referenced in relation to the One Billion Words Benchmark, which the LM model was pre-trained on for evaluating COMMONSENSEQA."
"Audiences are mentioned in the context of a question in COMMONSENSEQA, relating to social conventions."
"AtLocation is a CONCEPTNET relation used in COMMONSENSEQA to generate questions probing relationships between concepts."
"Development set is a part of COMMONSENSEQA used for analysis and model training."
"Answer concept refers to the concept that is the correct answer in a question from COMMONSENSEQA."
"Latent concepts are concepts that appear in the question or are implied, which are part of the commonsense skills needed to answer questions in COMMONSENSEQA."
"Labeled edges describe the commonsense skill that relates answer concepts to other concepts in the annotations of COMMONSENSEQA questions."
"First names are used by question formulators in COMMONSENSEQA to create context stories for questions."
"Hypothetical question refers to the use of 'if' to present hypothetical scenarios in questions formulated for COMMONSENSEQA."
"WHwords are words used as the first word in questions, representing a high variability in question language in COMMONSENSEQA."
"One Billion Words Benchmark is an event or dataset that the LM model was pre-trained on for evaluating COMMONSENSEQA."
"LM1B-CONCAT is a variation of the LM1B model where answers are concatenated to the question for evaluation in COMMONSENSEQA."
"LM1B-REP is a variation of the LM1B model where questions are rephrased as declarative sentences for evaluation in COMMONSENSEQA."
"High-frequency prefixes are patterns that cover a significant portion of the development set in COMMONSENSEQA, used to rephrase questions."
